lines.text: Come and have a bathe.
I'd like that.

[laughs]
That's the best conversation opening I've ever heard. "How do you do. Come and have a bathe."

He's the sort who can't know anyone intimately, least of all a woman. He doesn't know what a woman is. He wants you for a possession, something to look at, like a painting or an ivory box. Something to own and to display. He doesn't want you to be real, and to think and to live. He doesn't love you. But I love you. I want you to have your own thoughts and ideas and feelings, even when I hold you in my arms.
I don't care what I see outside. My vision is within! Here is where the birds sing! Here is where the sky is blue!
I shall never forgive myself.
You always say that, Charlotte, but you always do forgive yourself.
It's not coincidental that you're here now, when one comes to reflect on it.
I *have* reflected. It's fate. Everything is fate.
You've not reflected at all. Let me cross-examine you. Where did you meet Mr. Vyse, who will marry Miss Honeychurch?
The National Gallery.
Looking at Italian art! You see, you talk of coincidence and fate. You're naturally drawn to things Italian, as are we and all our friends, aren't we, Freddy? That narrows the field immeasurably.
It is fate. But call it Italy if it pleases you, Vicar.
Mother is calling, I have got to go. They trust me.
Why should they, when you deceived everyone, including yourself?
He has misbehaved from the first. In fact, he has behaved abominably.
Not abominably. He only tried when he should not have tried.
Mother doesn't like me playing Beethoven. She says I'm always peevish afterwards.
Naturally one would be... stirred up.
A young girl, transfigured by Italy! And why shouldn't she be transfigured? It happened to the Goths!
My father says there is only one perfect view, and that's the view of the sky over our heads.
I expect your father has been reading Dante.
We all have our little foibles, and mine is the prompt settling of accounts.
Why does she look like that?
Like what?

[imitating Charlotte]
Like Charlotte Bartlett.
Because, she *is* Charlotte Bartlett.
I would like to thank your father personally for his kindness to us.
You can't. He's in his bath.
Women like looking at a view. Men don't.
You don't love me, evidently. I dare say you're right not to, but... it would help a little, hurt a little less, if I knew why.
Because you're the sort who can't know anyone intimately, least of all a woman.
[Cecil looks taken aback and hurt]
Well, I don't mean exactly that, but you will go on asking questions!
How quickly these accidents do happen and then one returns to the old life.
I don't. I mean, something's happened to me... and to you.
Don't you agree that, on one's first visit to Florence, one must have a room with a view?
[last lines]
Kiss me, dear. Again.
I'm reading.
What are you reading?
It's from Freddy.
What does he say?
Silly boy. He thinks he's being dignified. I mean, everybody knew we were going away in the spring.
You must forgive me if I say stupid things. My brain has gone to pieces.
So you *do* love me, little thing.
Remember the facts about this church of Santa Croce; how it was built by faith in the full fervour of medievalism.
Built by faith indeed! That simply means the workers weren't paid properly.
I have no profession. My attitude - quite an indefensible one - is that as long as I am no trouble to anyone, I have the right to do as I like. It is, I dare say, an example of my decadence.
The train service has improved so!
I always travel by balloon.
In my small way I am a woman of the world. And I know where things can lead to.
Smell! A true Florentine smell. Inhale, my dear. Deeper! Every city, let me tell you, has its own smell.
Why need mother hear of it?
Well, you tell her everything, don't you?
I suppose I do, generally.
There's such a beautiful confidence between you. One would hate to break it. And as I have said before, I am to blame.
I wouldn't want mother to think so.
She will think so, if you tell her.
I shall never speak of it, either to mother or to anyone.
We will both be as silent as the grave.
Temper, Lucy. Temper, please!
[first lines]
This is not at all what we were led to expect.
I thought we were going to see the Arno.
The signora distinctly wrote, South rooms, with a view and close together, instead of which she has given us North rooms without a view and a long way apart.
You love George. You love the boy body and soul, as he loves you.

[crying]
But of course I do. What did you all think?
What is it about Italy that makes lady novelists reach such summits of absurdity?
